jurisdiction.title: Holy Spirit Catholic School Division - Alberta, Canada

D74BE86377F04F6690915F2E7085A4FB.description: Experience various dances that emerged from the United States of America.

312EB01D497D455BA2B5E535ABBE62F7.description: Observe different types of ballet as an inspiration for talking about and creating dance

3C406FF7E2804D36AF801265AC72E6D3.description: Use dance vocabulary when responding to or sharing opinions about dance

A0E1437DF2E14ADE9AF82AEAC6B1ED3B.description: Investigate how popular culture from the past and present may influence appreciation of dance.

4E7D0CEBF1F94FC293962ADE913E2F9C.description: Dance traditions existed prior to the colonization of the United States of America, and evolved as more people came to the land.

ED999BAB5B6A4D40BDBFA1AF0933DF44.description: The way in which dance is understood and appreciated today has changed throughout history

FA6CA8B0D0AB4D1099F28037EB1972C2.description: Appreciation of movement and dance can change through active reflection and experience with dance

D08D3408329543E3B12112FB519DF4CE.description: The Lindy Hop became a dance culture enjoyed by many races of people and that influenced the creation of other popular dance forms, including the jive, jitterbug, and boogie woogie

DDD4D6CC6C054E95B093F602F35F2A40.description: The fusion of African and European dance traditions formed dances, such as the Lindy Hop, in which dance partners separated to improvise movements in an individualized manner.

92CB394C1283445ABB2D65CF047348BC.description: During the Harlem Renaissance, social dancing became a way for the Black community to come together and celebrate being with one another.

CC09AFDAF58346CBA1B5B0F5436B7C52.description: As the United States of America became colonized, people brought with them a large and varied tradition of dance, which became known as folk dance

15F9934B74F645EBBCAD723A85CC1761.description: Before the colonization of the United States of America, the Indigenous people had rich and historical traditions of dance that continue to be celebrated today

3F344767F1C04B469514523C32E4196A.description: Dance during the French Revolution expressed narratives related to equality, freedom, and brotherhood.

10CF3DA1D858410598D9812BC406FF42.description: Ballet d'action was a popular form of dance during the French Revolution and was characterized by movements that conveyed character and emotion.

0D03C916C26B4024B1C3961B1B219C68.description: Ballet evolved from a social dance of the French royal courts, characterized by graceful arm and upper body movements, to being a timeless art form performed on a stage

9D3EB2BADFD74E5C9E27F0E0181AB1D5.description: Marie Salle was the first notable female ballet dancer to wear ballet slippers and a shortened skirt in order to perform more-complex ballet moves

4DA92955359546B1A4F79F5B37BE7E09.description: During the Enlightenment, ballet used narrative and music to communicate stories

9869A52AF4E64C1BA9D8AB41FF51CF7F.description: The Enlightenment saw the emergence of ballet as a valued art form, separate from opera and theatre

FB8BEE4B823040A2B991205DCEAC6436.description: Stylistic features and functions of dance from ancient societies influenced the evolution and creation of dance forms during the Enlightenment

B165F2D7557D479B8059522AA1753E07.description: Artistic traditions have changed over time to reflect popular (pop) culture as a form of expression from the people for the people

F8C4F9AF5DD1466AB6947E3054BA764F.description: Appreciation of dance can change with experience and inform future decisions regarding participation as a dancer and as an audience member

154841C2177546558034001E4A0E3CC2.description: Responses to and appreciation for dance can reflect personal preferences and perspectives

B28598A9E6BD41909ABC9E562AFB4600.description: Appreciation can shape individual artistry, curiosity, and engagement in dance.

02774F49367D495CAF8078D990FEF9C7.description: How did societal change influence dance during the Enlightenment, French Revolution, and throughout the history of the United States of America?

DF7BC7C8E5454B5E8D1EEF7E7D70647C.description: Appreciation: Recognizing beauty, goodness, and truth in dance can be developed by understanding the complexity and richness of great works of dance, the artists who create and perform them, and the historical and cultural contexts from which they originate

37AED37639CC4A2594E8FFE0A1ACB1C6.description: Evaluate the effectiveness of artistic choices when communicating intention in dance

241BE24D5B7D48888D189E9A1909CE29.description: Describe how feedback was incorporated to clarify or enhance artistic intention.

1BD5CDB09B4746A3B661A65A92DFDCF8.description: Create movement and dance ideas with the intention to explore new skills or movements

F02D5E032E434BD6B423E2EAAA73CBD9.description: Create and present dance for enjoyment.

D35015587E3A4B9F91EF7FB311B11A19.description: Participate in regular warm-up and cool-down activities in dance

CD05801136444CADA8FA1088708316C7.description: Practise movement skills to strengthen artistic expression in dance.

C7967FD45D3143CC8DFEDA90DCBFF449.description: Respond to a variety of stimuli in the creation and exploration of movement and dance ideas

7789797F47414947A98ED48A7D8A1F3A.description: Explore various styles of movement and dance.

DAE08318271F4258A56E735984527C0C.description: Experiment with how the elements of dance can be used symbolically

5948DC41B44E4ECBB0A5C0143FF8B02B.description: Create and perform dances based on a variety of inspirations.

3E8BAFDD596541288FC93DBC0E5BF673.description: Participate as a dancer and as an audience member in a variety of dance experiences

D561C64E297B4AF493423A57C896EECC.description: Rehearse movement ideas and dances prior to sharing with an audience.

0E7D2531AEFF4E3685402BF072A3C494.description: Collaborate when on and off stage during rehearsals and performances.

82A9A304CDD540B89FD4EF3137392820.description: Demonstrate how to follow cues when rehearsing and performing dance.

5AAFA7C8EDB8477397BCE2A85E9458E9.description: Incorporate a clear beginning, middle, and end into dance ideas

F126F9A9C04E4A0E8D9BF698788BBD3B.description: Choose how to structure a movement idea, phrase, or dance

8FFD54595FB54AA5B05FA1477BF57B64.description: A dancerï¿½s intention may emphasize process over product.

F05B186C39E946A18C212ACDFA3A8C38.description: Intention can be linked to the purposeful creation, expression, or appreciation of dance

E4E441BC19A9423D9BC579EA30B9BE3D.description: Intention refers to what a dancer means to express.

4C29876C396C426F91B065AAB9E457DF.description: Intention becomes evident to the dancer and audience when dances have structure and organization.

8D859C4ED7B04E1BAF4D8BAFA09CED4E.description: Artistic intention involves the process of decision making, problem solving, and reflection in the creation of dance

98244C3273E448A49163C01483D351DE.description: Learning a new dance skill or movement takes practice

D6E1CB07A7F44129B7F17E19C604D2C9.description: The creative process can be enhanced by taking creative risks, including working with various partners trying unfamiliar or new movements or skills implementing feedback working outside one's comfort zone

7A739087660042B18C1E7145EF7FFDC9.description: A dancer's artistic intention can be enhanced or refined by viewing the dances of other dancers practising movement skills participating in dance activities and warm-ups that prepare the body for expression creative processes

3C5AF9F1618A40C6AF00A61BEC171EF9.description: Music, as a stimulus for dance, can be chosen to highlight movement possibilities.

8AECE047140D4DC5AE651AF2EBD23642.description: A variety of stimuli can be used to focus intention

49BCCD26BAD3405C99ECF8222CF9695F.description: Styles of dance can be appreciated for the intentional use of dance steps, sequences, or stylistic features

D39B41B051C24198BAD6E6B59C29EE2C.description: Movement can intentionally and symbolically represent meaning through the use of space, including proximity, direction, levels, size, and pathways gestures and postures facial expressions force, weight, and flow creating shapes with the body stillness and balance

B760BF2586694A32B07660E4A9F12860.description: Movements executed with intention may be symbolic of mood, character, or theme

E94E30CA87944D4A8A120DA4E70667C6.description: Dance can intentionally communicate meaning in the way that movements are executed and organized.

BFA47E472F294F81A9F95559FF59701F.description: Intention can be communicated in dance through planned or improvised choreography

BE3B9EC2E12745739E218A02BD60D2EA.description: Some dances are structured intentionally to highlight features of a dance or dancers, including solos, duets, or small and large ensembles.

A3E59545729A408E850661C130934852.description: Repetition, contrast, and emphasis can help structure movement ideas

93BCF8CD09214A97B3D0AA204B74B3F1.description: Structure and organization in dance is achieved through choreographic forms a clear beginning, middle, and end collaboration cues from other dancers, music, or stimuli rehearsal and performance processes including use of onand off-stage areas

38634546516542999B118627DECEF795.description: How can intention strengthen communication of movement ideas?

4917B5560B0A44D8A9467573B890C676.description: Creating and presenting: Ideas can be represented through movement and dance that draw upon foundational knowledge.

A45E38849F894DC4BB041435913993B1.description: Share and demonstrate new movement ideas discovered during improvisations with other dancers

BADA388807B14EC2B4C9AF5B9C5B81CA.description: Collaborate in the creation and refinement of movements and dance

E09EB47257AB466FA0B98C10848E3AAB.description: Discuss challenges related to improvising movements individually and in groups.

5D238B35D63B472182374063CC2AC640.description: Apply problem-solving skills when moving individually and in groups.

78B6EFA40CC94BD49E04868DA767BBD1.description: Structure and share improvisations within a variety of choreographic forms

7FC8C82841014909AAC5B224E1B26817.description: Demonstrate an understanding of vocabulary related to the elements of dance and choreographic forms.

039D47EB89C24931B29197F1910B4A58.description: Combine movement ideas using the elements of dance

92A63E71359442C0AF1D600A6CCDD7C6.description: Improvisation fosters social interaction and development of perspectives.

ADFA5C7E01414EC6AF3121F5DFA4E2AA.description: Improvisation is responding and adapting appropriately to the unknown, to the environment, and to unexpected situations.

CC91548F2F5740DCBF21BAAD62B50839.description: Improvisation is a choreographic method used for creating, representing, and interpreting dance.

1A8DD37A391D4CD983147BD4968769FE.description: Improvisation can result in the discovery of new movement ideas

FC97B7286B4E47EA9E9D153ABA88921B.description: Improvisation includes opportunities to experiment and explore different techniques in a non-judgemental atmosphere

AE3C239491FD4C31A4C2EDAE78BAA5E2.description: Contact improvisation requires collaboration and physical contact between dancers

7A3ED8DFFC464ED3B0500B2F3F7A1198.description: Contact improvisation occurs when one dancer explores the elements of dance with another dancer.

411C59802E764C0EBB7F892F32D7B9E4.description: Improvisation can happen individually, with partners, or in groups.

E312FFA209004C65811EE7E2CE257C73.description: Thinking ahead while improvising movements can contribute to wellsequenced movements

4219D34F25F14CBB961E94594E0290ED.description: Problem-solving skills can be applied in the moment to avoid errors in dance formations, timing, or execution of movements

95876783F32145A5B373A3FA00ADB255.description: Improvisation in dance is spontaneous and requires thinking quickly in the moment

C94AB28C04A04036AD461630D738A044.description: Improvisations may not be interpreted in the way the dancer intended

5F19B4D4F7474E948B0639DB87AB679E.description: Improvisation does not require a dance idea to be performed the same way multiple times

43D0D73E235B40E98D2DA9C0AC329055.description: Parts or whole sections of dance can be improvised using choreographic forms, including ABACA (recurring theme) broken form that combines unrelated ideas chance dance, where movements are creating by responding to a stimuli like the roll of a die or an image

38286E028C1341AABFC401E66E6362B7.description: Improvisation draws upon the use of the elements of dance and variations in body, space, time, and force.

367EAD32D67A46358A53CA88E6D13EB1.description: How can improvisation broaden dance experiences and knowledge?

078A16BF04F945239B2B13FCF304EFE6.description: Foundational Elements and Principles: Dance literacy is developed through knowledge and application of foundational elements and principles
